Program Outline: Professional Certificate in Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence

  1.  Program Introduction and Information (Completed)
  2.  Navigating the Program (Completed)
  3.  Meet the Faculty (Completed)
  4.  Program Outline: Professional Certificate in Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence (Completed)
  5.  Passing Criteria (Completed)
  6.  Capstone Project Overview (Completed)
  7.  Program Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) ((Must view in order to complete this module item))

Back to Homepage

  •  Part 1: Modules 0-6
  •  Part 2: Modules 7-12
  • Part 3: Modules 13-24

Foundations of Machine Learning and AI

Module 0: Program Orientation

Key Activities

  • Program Introduction
  • Learning Platform Overview
  • Introduce Yourself
  • Program Agreement
Module 1: Introduction to Machine Learning

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify examples of the mystery box metaphor within your industry or personal experience.
  2. Establish the correct ML notation and concepts.
  3. Determine measures of discrete vs. continuous probability functions.
  4. Distinguish between measures of central tendency.
  5. Search for two data sources online and examine their characteristics.
  6. Identify functions and codes related to DataFrames.
  7. Load data into a DataFrame using pandas.
  8. Analyze data using selection and statistical techniques.
  9. Analyze different data visualization techniques.
  10. Create histograms and data visualizations.

Key Activities

  • Videos 1.1–1.6
  • Mini-Lessons 1.1–1.5
  • Required Knowledge Checks 1.1–1.6
  • Required Discussions 1.1–1.3
  • Required Codio Activities 1.1–1.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activities 1.1 and 1.2
  • Self-Study Colab Activity 1.1
Module 2: Fundamentals of Statistics and Distribution Functions

Learning Outcomes

  1. Differentiate between normal and uniform distributions.
  2. Evaluate measures of uniform distribution using SciPy. 
  3. Create and interpret visual plots, including probability density functions, histograms, scatter plots, pair plots, and correlation matrices.
  4. Discuss applications of the central limit theorem.
  5. Compute the mean and variance of univariate Gaussian distributions.
  6. Apply the law of large numbers to a given population.
  7. Explain covariance and correlation in multivariate distributions.
  8. Plot multivariate datasets.
  9. Compute measures of central tendency for univariate and multivariate distributions using pandas.
  10. Interpret a sample covariance matrix using Python.
  11. Identify correlations from scatter plots and conditional probabilities.

Key Activities

  • Videos 2.1–2.6
  • Mini-Lessons 2.1–2.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 2.1–1.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 2.1–2.4
  • Self-Study Discussion 2.1
  • Self-Study Try-It Activities 2.1 and 2.2
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 2.1–2.4
Module 3: Introduction to Data Analysis

Learning Outcomes

  1. Discuss real-world contexts for the data science lifecycle.
  2. Demonstrate the uses of different pandas functions.
  3. Manipulate data given a dataset.
  4. Choose appropriate visualizing functions.
  5. Generate visualizations using pandas, seaborn, and Plotly.
  6. Customize plots using externally sourced documentation.
  7. Use pandas.groupby to manipulate data.
  8. Demonstrate sorting and aggregating operations using pandas.
  9. Perform computations between DataFrames using set index and reset index.
  10. Demonstrate different indexing and filtering techniques using pandas.

Key Activities

  • Videos 3.1–3.10
  • Mini-Lessons 3.1–3.2
  • Required Knowledge Checks 3.1–3.4
  • Required Discussion 3.1
  • Required Codio Assignments 3.1–3.4
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 3.1
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 3.1–3.3
Module 4: Fundamentals of Data Analysis

Learning Outcomes

  1. Demonstrate pandas.merge to join datasets.
  2. Use pandas.merge to join with multiple fields using multiple variables in pandas.
  3. Perform merge operations on datasets.
  4. Use different plotting techniques in Seaborn and Plotly with pandas DataFrame to visualize the data.
  5. Create a variety of plot types in pandas, Seaborn, and Plotly.
  6. Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of each plotting library.
  7. Perform string manipulation in pandas.
  8. Import and clean messy data from real-world datasets.

Key Activities

  • Videos 4.1–4.11
  • Mini-Lessons 4.1–4.4
  • Required Knowledge Checks 4.1–4.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 4.1–4.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 4.1-4.5
Module 5: Practical Application 1

Learning Outcomes

  1. Create a GitHub portfolio.
  2. Apply exploratory data analysis, plotting, statistical summarization, and data visualization skills and techniques to a machine learning problem.

Key Activities

  • Video 5.1
  • Required Assignment 5.1
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 5.1
  • Self-Study Discussion 5.1
Module 6: Data Clustering and Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

Learning Outcomes

  1. Apply SVD to a specific dataset.
  2. Analyze the results of PCA in a specific context.
  3. Interpret the singular value and the results of PCA.
  4. Apply the k-means algorithm in Python.
  5. Compare the two different ways of initializing centroids (k-means++ vs. random initialization).
  6. Compare results of multiple clustering techniques on a given dataset.
  7. Interpret the results of k-means and PCA given an initial dataset.
  8. Evaluate various clustering algorithms by examining the clustering shapes and their ability to detect outliers in a given dataset.
  9. Draft a problem statement.

Key Activities

  • Videos 6.1–6.8
  • Mini-Lessons 6.1–6.4
  • Required Knowledge Checks 6.1–6.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 6.1–6.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 6.1 and 6.2

Machine Learning and AI Techniques

Module 7: Linear and Multiple Regressions

Learning Outcomes

  1. Differentiate between a linear and nonlinear model.
  2. Fit a simple linear regression model using scikit-learn and Plotly.
  3. Compute loss in prediction in order to minimize it.
  4. Compute the squared error and absolute error.
  5. Apply the scipy.optimize function to minimize the loss function.
  6. Apply multiple techniques to minimize a loss function.
  7. Recognize the use of mean absolute error (MAE) and mean squared error (MSE).
  8. Predict outcomes using a multiple linear regression model.
  9. Recognize ordinal, nominal, and categorical data within a dataset.

Key Activities

  • Videos 7.1–7.12
  • Mini-Lessons 7.1–7.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 7.1–7.7
  • Required Codio Assignments 7.1–7.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 7.1–7.2
Module 8: Feature Engineering and Overfitting

Learning Outcomes

  1. Articulate model fitting for nonlinear features.
  2. Generate nonlinear features for use by a linear model.
  3. Describe the difference between inference and prediction.
  4. Use scikit-learn transformers for generating polynomial features and prediction.
  5. Demonstrate the uses of different pandas functions.
  6. Articulate the definitions and relationships yielded from overfitting.
  7. Analyze the relationship between generalization and overfitting.
  8. Evaluate the complexity of various pipeline models.
  9. Select the best model based on validation data.
  10. Use a validation set for model selection to avoid overfitting.
  11. Use a test set for final model evaluation.
  12. Create and evaluate a linear regression model with nonlinear features using scikit-learn.

Key Activities

  • Videos 8.1–8.10
  • Mini-Lessons 8.1–8.5
  • Required Knowledge Checks 8.1–8.7
  • Required Codio Assignments 8.1–8.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 8.1–8.4
Module 9: Model Selection and Regularization

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the effect of polynomial features on Multidimensional data.
  2. Utilize sequential feature selection to explore model complexity.
  3. Apply regularization to control model complexity.
  4. Use regularization parameter "alpha" in ridge regression.
  5. Employ StandardScalar in ridge regularization.
  6. Scale data using standardization to avoid over-penalizing features in a regularized model.
  7. Apply GridSearchCV to select the optimal value for alpha.
  8. Select features using Lasso regression.
  9. Evaluate the differences between leave-one-out cross-validation, K-fold cross-validation, and holdout cross-validation.

Key Activities

  • Videos 9.1–9.11
  • Required Knowledge Checks 9.1–9.8
  • Required Codio Assignments 9.1–9.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 9.1–9.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 9.1
  • Self-Study Discussion 9.1
Module 10: Time Series Analysis and Forecasting

Learning Outcomes

  1. Describe the forecasting problem.
  2. Use modeling in time series forecasting with the effect of autocorrelations.
  3. Compute the sample autocorrelation and partial autocorrelation functions for a time series.
  4. Construct a model using classical time series decomposition.
  5. Differentiate between key characteristics of the autoregressive model and moving average model.
  6. Use the ACF and PACF to select the orders of an ARMA model.
  7. Interpret a forecast and its uncertainty.
  8. Determine the invertibility and stationarity of ARMA model and use ACF and PACF to select the order of ARMA model.

Key Activities

  • Videos 10.1–10.13
  • Mini-Lessons 10.1 and 10.2
  • Required Knowledge Checks 10.1–10.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 10.1–10.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 10.1–10.3
Module 11: Practical Application 2

Learning Outcomes

  1. Apply the CRISP-DM framework to a business problem.

Key Activities

  • Videos 11.1 and 11.2
  • Required Assignment 11.1
Module 12: Classification and k-Nearest Neighbors

Learning Outcomes

  1. Explain the concept of classification with an email spam detection example.
  2. Train a nearest neighbor classifier using cross-validation.
  3. Use k to minimize misclassification error.
  4. Use cross-validation to pick hyperparameters that optimize the metric of your choosing.
  5. Describe the effect on threshold and choice of k using the predict_proba function in scikit-learn.
  6. Create a visualization of KNN decision boundaries as a function of k and threshold.
  7. Assess the trade-offs between classifier metrics.
  8. Compute the real value output by using a regression function with KNN.
  9. Compare the accuracy and interpretability of a properly trained linear regression and a KNN regression model.

Key Activities

  • Videos 12.1–12.10
  • Mini-Lessons 12.1–12.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 12.1–12.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 12.1–12.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 12.1–12.3

Advanced Topics and Capstone

Module 13: Logistic Regression

Learning Outcomes

  1. Analyze the characteristics and advantages of logistic regression.
  2. Use the scikit-learn framework to solve a basic logistic regression problem.
  3. Utilize logistic regression for business decision-making.
  4. Practice illustrating logistic regression as an optimization problem to determine the coefficients to minimize cross-entropy.
  5. Implement strategies to visualize decision boundaries for two variables.
  6. Evaluate the cross-entropy for a range of parameters.
  7. Apply logistic regression to generate multiclass outputs.
  8. Use L1 regularization to select features.
  9. Assess multiple models using performance metrics.

Key Activities

  • Videos 13.1–13.7
  • Mini-Lesson 13.1
  • Required Knowledge Checks 13.1–13.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 13.1–13.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 13.1–13.4
Module 14: Decision Trees

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the correct statements regarding decision trees and their outputs.
  2. Build a decision tree manually.
  3. Articulate the correct inputs for building decision trees using scikit-learn and visualizing them using Graphiz.
  4. Train a decision tree model with desired hyperparameters using scikit-learn.
  5. Visualize a decision tree.
  6. Evaluate decision tree splits.
  7. Evaluate overfitting of decision trees.
  8. Measure the impurity of a decision tree using entropy.
  9. Compare the performance of different grid search algorithms.
  10. Implement the decision tree algorithm.

Key Activities

  • Videos 14.1–14.11
  • Mini-Lessons 14.1–14.5
  • Required Knowledge Checks 14.1–14.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 14.1–14.3
  • Required Discussion 14.1
  • Required Try-It Activity 14.2
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 14.1–14.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 14.1
Module 15: Gradient Descent and Optimization

Learning Outcomes

  1. Compute the approximate value of a function using its derivative.
  2. Identify the basics of gradient descent and the impact of learning rate on convergence.
  3. Compute x and/or y for each iteration of gradient descent.
  4. Optimize a single-parameter linear regression model from scratch.
  5. Recognize convex one-dimensional and two-dimensional functions.
  6. Compute the gradient of a two-dimensional function.
  7. Measure the impurity of a decision tree using entropy.
  8. Use gradient descent to optimize a nonlinear two-dimensional regression model.
  9. Use stochastic gradient descent to optimize a nonlinear two-dimensional regression model.
  10. Compare the convergence behavior of gradient descent with stochastic gradient descent.
  11. Articulate the impact of stochastic gradient on bias and variance.

Key Activities

  • Videos 15.1–15.15
  • Required Knowledge Checks 15.1–15.6
  • Required Codio Assignments 15.1–15.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 15.1–15.4
Module 16: Classifying Nonlinear Features

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify nonlinear features in a dataset.
  2. Compare classification models to assess boundary definitions.
  3. Apply kernels to logistic regression models to automatically build nonlinear boundaries.
  4. Compare large- and small-margin classifiers.
  5. Calculate the maximum margin given a dataset.
  6. Create maximum margin classifier visualizations in scikit-learn.
  7. Articulate the working of the kernel functions in SVM using scikit-learn.
  8. Tune kernel and regularization parameters given a dataset.
  9. Discuss the results and trade-offs of various techniques.
  10. Refine your problem statement to include a research question, expected data sources and structure, expected results and techniques.

Key Activities

  • Videos 16.1–16.6
  • Mini-Lesson 16.1
  • Required Knowledge Checks 16.1–16.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 16.1 and 16.2
  • Required Discussion 16.1
  • Required Capstone Assignment 16.1
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 16.1–16.6
Module 17: Practical Application 3

Learning Outcomes

  1. Apply various classification methods to a business problem.
  2. Compare the results of k-nearest neighbors, logistic regression, decision trees, and support vector machines.

Key Activities

  • Videos 17.1 and 17.2
  • Required Assignment 17.1
Module 18: Natural Language Processing (NLP)

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the similarities and differences between text and numerical data.
  2. Convert text data to numerical data using NLTK.
  3. Tokenize blocks of text.
  4. Decide what features to extract from a text for a particular classification purpose.
  5. Implement feature extraction using NLTK.
  6. Use Bag-of-Words and TF-IDF algorithms to convert text data to numerical representation.
  7. Classify text data using Bag-of-Words, TF-IDF, and logistic regression algorithms.
  8. Compare the results of classification on text data using several models.
  9. Apply the naïve Bayes classifier.

Key Activities

  • Videos 18.1–18.6
  • Mini-Lessons 18.1–18.7
  • Required Knowledge Checks 18.1–18.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 18.1–18.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 18.1–18.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 18.1
Module 19: Recommendation Systems

Learning Outcomes

  1. Compute missing ratings from a rating dataset.
  2. Evaluate the trade-off between the number of factors and model performance.
  3. Calculate users' predictions using linear regression.
  4. Utilize collaborative filtering to understand users' predictions.
  5. Implement the Simon Funk SVD gradient descent algorithm for collaborative filtering.
  6. Use the SURPRISE library to build and analyze recommender systems on real datasets.
  7. Articulate the significance of a hybrid recommendation system.
  8. Determine why a surprise recommendation may occur on a recommendation system.

Key Activities

  • Videos 19.1–19.9
  • Mini-Lessons 19.1–19.4
  • Required Knowledge Checks 19.1–19.6
  • Required Codio Assignments 19.1–19.3
  • Required Discussion 19.1
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 19.1–19.3
  • Self-Study Discussion 19.1
Module 20: Ensemble Techniques

Learning Outcomes

  1. Relate the concepts of bias and variance to real-world examples.
  2. Employ the concept of aggregating predictors for bagging in ensemble model.
  3. Build a metamodel for classification and regression problems.
  4. Evaluate the performance of various metamodels.
  5. Implement bootstrapping on a dataset.
  6. Implement bagging on a metamodel.
  7. Apply out-of-bag evaluation in scikit-learn.
  8. Articulate the key concepts and parameters of the Random Forest algorithm in scikit-learn.
  9. Design random forests for classification and regression problems.
  10. Implement the AdaBoost algorithm.
  11. Compare the AdaBoost algorithm with gradient boosted trees.
  12. Perform a deep analysis of your identified problem in order to develop an executive brief detailing your technical findings.

Key Activities

  • Videos 20.1–20.9
  • Mini-Lessons 20.1
  • Required Knowledge Checks 20.1–20.6
  • Required Try-It Activity 20.1
  • Required Codio Assignments 20.1–20.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 20.1–20.3
Module 21: Deep Neural Networks (Part 1)

Learning Outcomes

  1. Articulate the basics and evolution of neural networks.
  2. Compute the output of a neural network given parameters and data.
  3. Train a simple neural network.
  4. Apply the basics of Keras for developing machine learning models.
  5. Use Keras to create, compile, fit, and evaluate a model.
  6. Select the appropriate output layer and loss function for multiclass classification.
  7. Adjust hyperparameters and model architecture to maximize model generalizability.

Key Activities

  • Videos 21.1–21.9
  • Mini-Lessons 21.1 and 21.2
  • Required Knowledge Checks 21.1–21.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 21.1–21.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 21.1–21.6
Module 22: Deep Neural Networks (Part 2)

Learning Outcomes

  1. Articulate the basics of a CNN and its different layers.
  2. Process images in preparation for training a neural network.
  3. Train a neural network to recognize items and images.
  4. Use a pretrained network to enhance model performance.
  5. Interpret a neural network model.
  6. Compare an LSTM network to time series analysis.
  7. Train an LSTM network for time series analysis.
  8. Apply neural network techniques to a linear regression problem.
  9. Apply AI/ML techniques to a specific field you are interested in.

Key Activities

  • Videos 22.1–22.7
  • Mini-Lessons 22.1–22.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 22.1–22.3
  • Required Codio Assignments 22.1–22.5
  • Self-Study Discussion 22.1
  • Self-Study Try-It Activities 22.1–22.2
Module 23: Generative AI

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the limitations of generative techniques.
  2. Distinguish between the learning techniques of Gen AI.
  3. Configure a diffusion model to generate personalized AI images.
  4. Test different Gen AI models to compare similarities and differences.
  5. Generate a narrative using AI text generators in order to effectively evaluate data patterns.
  6. Calculate the similarity between sentences using transformers.
  7. Evaluate the effectiveness of Gen AI application examples.
  8. Identify current business applications of Gen AI technologies in finance, education, or healthcare.
  9. Generate a prompt for a Gen AI platform in order to analyze its effectiveness.

Key Activities

  • Videos 23.1–23.8
  • Mini-Lessons 23.1–23.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 23.1–23.2
  • Required Codio Assignment 23.1
  • Required Discussion 23.1-23.2
  • Required Assignment 23.1
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 23.1–23.2
  • Self-Study Discussions 23.1–23.2
Module 24: Capstone

Learning Outcomes

  1. Develop a nontechnical report for your comprehensive data solution that effectively addresses a real-world problem.

Key Activities

  • Video 24.1
  • Mini-Lesson 24.1
  • Required Capstone Project 24.1

Foundations of Machine Learning and AI

Module 0: Program Orientation

Key Activities

  • Program Introduction
  • Learning Platform Overview
  • Introduce Yourself
  • Program Agreement
Module 1: Introduction to Machine Learning

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify examples of the mystery box metaphor within your industry or personal experience.
  2. Establish the correct ML notation and concepts.
  3. Determine measures of discrete vs. continuous probability functions.
  4. Distinguish between measures of central tendency.
  5. Search for two data sources online and examine their characteristics.
  6. Identify functions and codes related to DataFrames.
  7. Load data into a DataFrame using pandas.
  8. Analyze data using selection and statistical techniques.
  9. Analyze different data visualization techniques.
  10. Create histograms and data visualizations.

Key Activities

  • Videos 1.1–1.6
  • Mini-Lessons 1.1–1.5
  • Required Knowledge Checks 1.1–1.6
  • Required Discussions 1.1–1.3
  • Required Codio Activities 1.1–1.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activities 1.1 and 1.2
  • Self-Study Colab Activity 1.1
Module 2: Fundamentals of Statistics and Distribution Functions

Learning Outcomes

  1. Differentiate between normal and uniform distributions.
  2. Evaluate measures of uniform distribution using SciPy. 
  3. Create and interpret visual plots, including probability density functions, histograms, scatter plots, pair plots, and correlation matrices.
  4. Discuss applications of the central limit theorem.
  5. Compute the mean and variance of univariate Gaussian distributions.
  6. Apply the law of large numbers to a given population.
  7. Explain covariance and correlation in multivariate distributions.
  8. Plot multivariate datasets.
  9. Compute measures of central tendency for univariate and multivariate distributions using pandas.
  10. Interpret a sample covariance matrix using Python.
  11. Identify correlations from scatter plots and conditional probabilities.

Key Activities

  • Videos 2.1–2.6
  • Mini-Lessons 2.1–2.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 2.1–1.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 2.1–2.4
  • Self-Study Discussion 2.1
  • Self-Study Try-It Activities 2.1 and 2.2
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 2.1–2.4
Module 3: Introduction to Data Analysis

Learning Outcomes

  1. Discuss real-world contexts for the data science lifecycle.
  2. Demonstrate the uses of different pandas functions.
  3. Manipulate data given a dataset.
  4. Choose appropriate visualizing functions.
  5. Generate visualizations using pandas, seaborn, and Plotly.
  6. Customize plots using externally sourced documentation.
  7. Use pandas.groupby to manipulate data.
  8. Demonstrate sorting and aggregating operations using pandas.
  9. Perform computations between DataFrames using set index and reset index.
  10. Demonstrate different indexing and filtering techniques using pandas.

Key Activities

  • Videos 3.1–3.10
  • Mini-Lessons 3.1–3.2
  • Required Knowledge Checks 3.1–3.4
  • Required Discussion 3.1
  • Required Codio Assignments 3.1–3.4
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 3.1
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 3.1–3.3
Module 4: Fundamentals of Data Analysis

Learning Outcomes

  1. Demonstrate pandas.merge to join datasets.
  2. Use pandas.merge to join with multiple fields using multiple variables in pandas.
  3. Perform merge operations on datasets.
  4. Use different plotting techniques in Seaborn and Plotly with pandas DataFrame to visualize the data.
  5. Create a variety of plot types in pandas, Seaborn, and Plotly.
  6. Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of each plotting library.
  7. Perform string manipulation in pandas.
  8. Import and clean messy data from real-world datasets.

Key Activities

  • Videos 4.1–4.11
  • Mini-Lessons 4.1–4.4
  • Required Knowledge Checks 4.1–4.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 4.1–4.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 4.1-4.5
Module 5: Practical Application 1

Learning Outcomes

  1. Create a GitHub portfolio.
  2. Apply exploratory data analysis, plotting, statistical summarization, and data visualization skills and techniques to a machine learning problem.

Key Activities

  • Video 5.1
  • Required Assignment 5.1
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 5.1
  • Self-Study Discussion 5.1
Module 6: Data Clustering and Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

Learning Outcomes

  1. Apply SVD to a specific dataset.
  2. Analyze the results of PCA in a specific context.
  3. Interpret the singular value and the results of PCA.
  4. Apply the k-means algorithm in Python.
  5. Compare the two different ways of initializing centroids (k-means++ vs. random initialization).
  6. Compare results of multiple clustering techniques on a given dataset.
  7. Interpret the results of k-means and PCA given an initial dataset.
  8. Evaluate various clustering algorithms by examining the clustering shapes and their ability to detect outliers in a given dataset.
  9. Draft a problem statement.

Key Activities

  • Videos 6.1–6.8
  • Mini-Lessons 6.1–6.4
  • Required Knowledge Checks 6.1–6.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 6.1–6.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 6.1 and 6.2

Machine Learning and AI Techniques

Module 7: Linear and Multiple Regressions

Learning Outcomes

  1. Differentiate between a linear and nonlinear model.
  2. Fit a simple linear regression model using scikit-learn and Plotly.
  3. Compute loss in prediction in order to minimize it.
  4. Compute the squared error and absolute error.
  5. Apply the scipy.optimize function to minimize the loss function.
  6. Apply multiple techniques to minimize a loss function.
  7. Recognize the use of mean absolute error (MAE) and mean squared error (MSE).
  8. Predict outcomes using a multiple linear regression model.
  9. Recognize ordinal, nominal, and categorical data within a dataset.

Key Activities

  • Videos 7.1–7.12
  • Mini-Lessons 7.1–7.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 7.1–7.7
  • Required Codio Assignments 7.1–7.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 7.1–7.2
Module 8: Feature Engineering and Overfitting

Learning Outcomes

  1. Articulate model fitting for nonlinear features.
  2. Generate nonlinear features for use by a linear model.
  3. Describe the difference between inference and prediction.
  4. Use scikit-learn transformers for generating polynomial features and prediction.
  5. Demonstrate the uses of different pandas functions.
  6. Articulate the definitions and relationships yielded from overfitting.
  7. Analyze the relationship between generalization and overfitting.
  8. Evaluate the complexity of various pipeline models.
  9. Select the best model based on validation data.
  10. Use a validation set for model selection to avoid overfitting.
  11. Use a test set for final model evaluation.
  12. Create and evaluate a linear regression model with nonlinear features using scikit-learn.

Key Activities

  • Videos 8.1–8.10
  • Mini-Lessons 8.1–8.5
  • Required Knowledge Checks 8.1–8.7
  • Required Codio Assignments 8.1–8.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 8.1–8.4
Module 9: Model Selection and Regularization

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the effect of polynomial features on Multidimensional data.
  2. Utilize sequential feature selection to explore model complexity.
  3. Apply regularization to control model complexity.
  4. Use regularization parameter "alpha" in ridge regression.
  5. Employ StandardScalar in ridge regularization.
  6. Scale data using standardization to avoid over-penalizing features in a regularized model.
  7. Apply GridSearchCV to select the optimal value for alpha.
  8. Select features using Lasso regression.
  9. Evaluate the differences between leave-one-out cross-validation, K-fold cross-validation, and holdout cross-validation.

Key Activities

  • Videos 9.1–9.11
  • Required Knowledge Checks 9.1–9.8
  • Required Codio Assignments 9.1–9.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 9.1–9.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 9.1
  • Self-Study Discussion 9.1
Module 10: Time Series Analysis and Forecasting

Learning Outcomes

  1. Describe the forecasting problem.
  2. Use modeling in time series forecasting with the effect of autocorrelations.
  3. Compute the sample autocorrelation and partial autocorrelation functions for a time series.
  4. Construct a model using classical time series decomposition.
  5. Differentiate between key characteristics of the autoregressive model and moving average model.
  6. Use the ACF and PACF to select the orders of an ARMA model.
  7. Interpret a forecast and its uncertainty.
  8. Determine the invertibility and stationarity of ARMA model and use ACF and PACF to select the order of ARMA model.

Key Activities

  • Videos 10.1–10.13
  • Mini-Lessons 10.1 and 10.2
  • Required Knowledge Checks 10.1–10.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 10.1–10.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 10.1–10.3
Module 11: Practical Application 2

Learning Outcomes

  1. Apply the CRISP-DM framework to a business problem.

Key Activities

  • Videos 11.1 and 11.2
  • Required Assignment 11.1
Module 12: Classification and k-Nearest Neighbors

Learning Outcomes

  1. Explain the concept of classification with an email spam detection example.
  2. Train a nearest neighbor classifier using cross-validation.
  3. Use k to minimize misclassification error.
  4. Use cross-validation to pick hyperparameters that optimize the metric of your choosing.
  5. Describe the effect on threshold and choice of k using the predict_proba function in scikit-learn.
  6. Create a visualization of KNN decision boundaries as a function of k and threshold.
  7. Assess the trade-offs between classifier metrics.
  8. Compute the real value output by using a regression function with KNN.
  9. Compare the accuracy and interpretability of a properly trained linear regression and a KNN regression model.

Key Activities

  • Videos 12.1–12.10
  • Mini-Lessons 12.1–12.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 12.1–12.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 12.1–12.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 12.1–12.3

Advanced Topics and Capstone

Module 13: Logistic Regression

Learning Outcomes

  1. Analyze the characteristics and advantages of logistic regression.
  2. Use the scikit-learn framework to solve a basic logistic regression problem.
  3. Utilize logistic regression for business decision-making.
  4. Practice illustrating logistic regression as an optimization problem to determine the coefficients to minimize cross-entropy.
  5. Implement strategies to visualize decision boundaries for two variables.
  6. Evaluate the cross-entropy for a range of parameters.
  7. Apply logistic regression to generate multiclass outputs.
  8. Use L1 regularization to select features.
  9. Assess multiple models using performance metrics.

Key Activities

  • Videos 13.1–13.7
  • Mini-Lesson 13.1
  • Required Knowledge Checks 13.1–13.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 13.1–13.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 13.1–13.4
Module 14: Decision Trees

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the correct statements regarding decision trees and their outputs.
  2. Build a decision tree manually.
  3. Articulate the correct inputs for building decision trees using scikit-learn and visualizing them using Graphiz.
  4. Train a decision tree model with desired hyperparameters using scikit-learn.
  5. Visualize a decision tree.
  6. Evaluate decision tree splits.
  7. Evaluate overfitting of decision trees.
  8. Measure the impurity of a decision tree using entropy.
  9. Compare the performance of different grid search algorithms.
  10. Implement the decision tree algorithm.

Key Activities

  • Videos 14.1–14.11
  • Mini-Lessons 14.1–14.5
  • Required Knowledge Checks 14.1–14.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 14.1–14.3
  • Required Discussion 14.1
  • Required Try-It Activity 14.2
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 14.1–14.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 14.1
Module 15: Gradient Descent and Optimization

Learning Outcomes

  1. Compute the approximate value of a function using its derivative.
  2. Identify the basics of gradient descent and the impact of learning rate on convergence.
  3. Compute x and/or y for each iteration of gradient descent.
  4. Optimize a single-parameter linear regression model from scratch.
  5. Recognize convex one-dimensional and two-dimensional functions.
  6. Compute the gradient of a two-dimensional function.
  7. Measure the impurity of a decision tree using entropy.
  8. Use gradient descent to optimize a nonlinear two-dimensional regression model.
  9. Use stochastic gradient descent to optimize a nonlinear two-dimensional regression model.
  10. Compare the convergence behavior of gradient descent with stochastic gradient descent.
  11. Articulate the impact of stochastic gradient on bias and variance.

Key Activities

  • Videos 15.1–15.15
  • Required Knowledge Checks 15.1–15.6
  • Required Codio Assignments 15.1–15.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 15.1–15.4
Module 16: Classifying Nonlinear Features

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify nonlinear features in a dataset.
  2. Compare classification models to assess boundary definitions.
  3. Apply kernels to logistic regression models to automatically build nonlinear boundaries.
  4. Compare large- and small-margin classifiers.
  5. Calculate the maximum margin given a dataset.
  6. Create maximum margin classifier visualizations in scikit-learn.
  7. Articulate the working of the kernel functions in SVM using scikit-learn.
  8. Tune kernel and regularization parameters given a dataset.
  9. Discuss the results and trade-offs of various techniques.
  10. Refine your problem statement to include a research question, expected data sources and structure, expected results and techniques.

Key Activities

  • Videos 16.1–16.6
  • Mini-Lesson 16.1
  • Required Knowledge Checks 16.1–16.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 16.1 and 16.2
  • Required Discussion 16.1
  • Required Capstone Assignment 16.1
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 16.1–16.6
Module 17: Practical Application 3

Learning Outcomes

  1. Apply various classification methods to a business problem.
  2. Compare the results of k-nearest neighbors, logistic regression, decision trees, and support vector machines.

Key Activities

  • Videos 17.1 and 17.2
  • Required Assignment 17.1
Module 18: Natural Language Processing (NLP)

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the similarities and differences between text and numerical data.
  2. Convert text data to numerical data using NLTK.
  3. Tokenize blocks of text.
  4. Decide what features to extract from a text for a particular classification purpose.
  5. Implement feature extraction using NLTK.
  6. Use Bag-of-Words and TF-IDF algorithms to convert text data to numerical representation.
  7. Classify text data using Bag-of-Words, TF-IDF, and logistic regression algorithms.
  8. Compare the results of classification on text data using several models.
  9. Apply the naïve Bayes classifier.

Key Activities

  • Videos 18.1–18.6
  • Mini-Lessons 18.1–18.7
  • Required Knowledge Checks 18.1–18.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 18.1–18.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 18.1–18.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 18.1
Module 19: Recommendation Systems

Learning Outcomes

  1. Compute missing ratings from a rating dataset.
  2. Evaluate the trade-off between the number of factors and model performance.
  3. Calculate users' predictions using linear regression.
  4. Utilize collaborative filtering to understand users' predictions.
  5. Implement the Simon Funk SVD gradient descent algorithm for collaborative filtering.
  6. Use the SURPRISE library to build and analyze recommender systems on real datasets.
  7. Articulate the significance of a hybrid recommendation system.
  8. Determine why a surprise recommendation may occur on a recommendation system.

Key Activities

  • Videos 19.1–19.9
  • Mini-Lessons 19.1–19.4
  • Required Knowledge Checks 19.1–19.6
  • Required Codio Assignments 19.1–19.3
  • Required Discussion 19.1
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 19.1–19.3
  • Self-Study Discussion 19.1
Module 20: Ensemble Techniques

Learning Outcomes

  1. Relate the concepts of bias and variance to real-world examples.
  2. Employ the concept of aggregating predictors for bagging in ensemble model.
  3. Build a metamodel for classification and regression problems.
  4. Evaluate the performance of various metamodels.
  5. Implement bootstrapping on a dataset.
  6. Implement bagging on a metamodel.
  7. Apply out-of-bag evaluation in scikit-learn.
  8. Articulate the key concepts and parameters of the Random Forest algorithm in scikit-learn.
  9. Design random forests for classification and regression problems.
  10. Implement the AdaBoost algorithm.
  11. Compare the AdaBoost algorithm with gradient boosted trees.
  12. Perform a deep analysis of your identified problem in order to develop an executive brief detailing your technical findings.

Key Activities

  • Videos 20.1–20.9
  • Mini-Lessons 20.1
  • Required Knowledge Checks 20.1–20.6
  • Required Try-It Activity 20.1
  • Required Codio Assignments 20.1–20.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 20.1–20.3
Module 21: Deep Neural Networks (Part 1)

Learning Outcomes

  1. Articulate the basics and evolution of neural networks.
  2. Compute the output of a neural network given parameters and data.
  3. Train a simple neural network.
  4. Apply the basics of Keras for developing machine learning models.
  5. Use Keras to create, compile, fit, and evaluate a model.
  6. Select the appropriate output layer and loss function for multiclass classification.
  7. Adjust hyperparameters and model architecture to maximize model generalizability.

Key Activities

  • Videos 21.1–21.9
  • Mini-Lessons 21.1 and 21.2
  • Required Knowledge Checks 21.1–21.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 21.1–21.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 21.1–21.6
Module 22: Deep Neural Networks (Part 2)

Learning Outcomes

  1. Articulate the basics of a CNN and its different layers.
  2. Process images in preparation for training a neural network.
  3. Train a neural network to recognize items and images.
  4. Use a pretrained network to enhance model performance.
  5. Interpret a neural network model.
  6. Compare an LSTM network to time series analysis.
  7. Train an LSTM network for time series analysis.
  8. Apply neural network techniques to a linear regression problem.
  9. Apply AI/ML techniques to a specific field you are interested in.

Key Activities

  • Videos 22.1–22.7
  • Mini-Lessons 22.1–22.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 22.1–22.3
  • Required Codio Assignments 22.1–22.5
  • Self-Study Discussion 22.1
  • Self-Study Try-It Activities 22.1–22.2
Module 23: Generative AI

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the limitations of generative techniques.
  2. Distinguish between the learning techniques of Gen AI.
  3. Configure a diffusion model to generate personalized AI images.
  4. Test different Gen AI models to compare similarities and differences.
  5. Generate a narrative using AI text generators in order to effectively evaluate data patterns.
  6. Calculate the similarity between sentences using transformers.
  7. Evaluate the effectiveness of Gen AI application examples.
  8. Identify current business applications of Gen AI technologies in finance, education, or healthcare.
  9. Generate a prompt for a Gen AI platform in order to analyze its effectiveness.

Key Activities

  • Videos 23.1–23.8
  • Mini-Lessons 23.1–23.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 23.1–23.2
  • Required Codio Assignment 23.1
  • Required Discussion 23.1-23.2
  • Required Assignment 23.1
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 23.1–23.2
  • Self-Study Discussions 23.1–23.2
Module 24: Capstone

Learning Outcomes

  1. Develop a nontechnical report for your comprehensive data solution that effectively addresses a real-world problem.

Key Activities

  • Video 24.1
  • Mini-Lesson 24.1
  • Required Capstone Project 24.1

Foundations of Machine Learning and AI

Module 0: Program Orientation

Key Activities

  • Program Introduction
  • Learning Platform Overview
  • Introduce Yourself
  • Program Agreement
Module 1: Introduction to Machine Learning

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify examples of the mystery box metaphor within your industry or personal experience.
  2. Establish the correct ML notation and concepts.
  3. Determine measures of discrete vs. continuous probability functions.
  4. Distinguish between measures of central tendency.
  5. Search for two data sources online and examine their characteristics.
  6. Identify functions and codes related to DataFrames.
  7. Load data into a DataFrame using pandas.
  8. Analyze data using selection and statistical techniques.
  9. Analyze different data visualization techniques.
  10. Create histograms and data visualizations.

Key Activities

  • Videos 1.1–1.6
  • Mini-Lessons 1.1–1.5
  • Required Knowledge Checks 1.1–1.6
  • Required Discussions 1.1–1.3
  • Required Codio Activities 1.1–1.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activities 1.1 and 1.2
  • Self-Study Colab Activity 1.1
Module 2: Fundamentals of Statistics and Distribution Functions

Learning Outcomes

  1. Differentiate between normal and uniform distributions.
  2. Evaluate measures of uniform distribution using SciPy. 
  3. Create and interpret visual plots, including probability density functions, histograms, scatter plots, pair plots, and correlation matrices.
  4. Discuss applications of the central limit theorem.
  5. Compute the mean and variance of univariate Gaussian distributions.
  6. Apply the law of large numbers to a given population.
  7. Explain covariance and correlation in multivariate distributions.
  8. Plot multivariate datasets.
  9. Compute measures of central tendency for univariate and multivariate distributions using pandas.
  10. Interpret a sample covariance matrix using Python.
  11. Identify correlations from scatter plots and conditional probabilities.

Key Activities

  • Videos 2.1–2.6
  • Mini-Lessons 2.1–2.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 2.1–1.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 2.1–2.4
  • Self-Study Discussion 2.1
  • Self-Study Try-It Activities 2.1 and 2.2
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 2.1–2.4
Module 3: Introduction to Data Analysis

Learning Outcomes

  1. Discuss real-world contexts for the data science lifecycle.
  2. Demonstrate the uses of different pandas functions.
  3. Manipulate data given a dataset.
  4. Choose appropriate visualizing functions.
  5. Generate visualizations using pandas, seaborn, and Plotly.
  6. Customize plots using externally sourced documentation.
  7. Use pandas.groupby to manipulate data.
  8. Demonstrate sorting and aggregating operations using pandas.
  9. Perform computations between DataFrames using set index and reset index.
  10. Demonstrate different indexing and filtering techniques using pandas.

Key Activities

  • Videos 3.1–3.10

  • Self-Study Colab Activities 3.1–3.3
Module 4: Fundamentals of Data Analysis

Learning Outcomes

  1. Demonstrate pandas.merge to join datasets.
  2. Use pandas.merge to join with multiple fields using multiple variables in pandas.
  3. Perform merge operations on datasets.
  4. Use different plotting techniques in Seaborn and Plotly with pandas DataFrame to visualize the data.
  5. Create a variety of plot types in pandas, Seaborn, and Plotly.
  6. Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of each plotting library.
  7. Perform string manipulation in pandas.
  8. Import and clean messy data from real-world datasets.

  • Mini-Lessons 4.1–4.4

  • Self-Study Colab Activities 13.1–13.4
Module 14: Decision Trees

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the correct statements regarding decision trees and their outputs.
  2. Build a decision tree manually.
  3. Articulate the correct inputs for building decision trees using scikit-learn and visualizing them using Graphiz.
  4. Train a decision tree model with desired hyperparameters using scikit-learn.
  5. Visualize a decision tree.
  6. Evaluate decision tree splits.
  7. Evaluate overfitting of decision trees.
  8. Measure the impurity of a decision tree using entropy.
  9. Compare the performance of different grid search algorithms.
  10. Implement the decision tree algorithm.

Key Activities

  • Videos 14.1–14.11
  • Mini-Lessons 14.1–14.5
  • Required Knowledge Checks 14.1–14.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 14.1–14.3
  • Required Discussion 14.1
  • Required Try-It Activity 14.2
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 14.1–14.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 14.1
Module 15: Gradient Descent and Optimization

Learning Outcomes

  1. Compute the approximate value of a function using its derivative.
  2. Identify the basics of gradient descent and the impact of learning rate on convergence.
  3. Compute x and/or y for each iteration of gradient descent.
  4. Optimize a single-parameter linear regression model from scratch.
  5. Recognize convex one-dimensional and two-dimensional functions.
  6. Compute the gradient of a two-dimensional function.
  7. Measure the impurity of a decision tree using entropy.
  8. Use gradient descent to optimize a nonlinear two-dimensional regression model.
  9. Use stochastic gradient descent to optimize a nonlinear two-dimensional regression model.
  10. Compare the convergence behavior of gradient descent with stochastic gradient descent.
  11. Articulate the impact of stochastic gradient on bias and variance.

Key Activities

  • Videos 15.1–15.15
  • Required Knowledge Checks 15.1–15.6
  • Required Codio Assignments 15.1–15.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 15.1–15.4
Module 16: Classifying Nonlinear Features

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify nonlinear features in a dataset.
  2. Compare classification models to assess boundary definitions.
  3. Apply kernels to logistic regression models to automatically build nonlinear boundaries.
  4. Compare large- and small-margin classifiers.
  5. Calculate the maximum margin given a dataset.
  6. Create maximum margin classifier visualizations in scikit-learn.
  7. Articulate the working of the kernel functions in SVM using scikit-learn.
  8. Tune kernel and regularization parameters given a dataset.
  9. Discuss the results and trade-offs of various techniques.
  10. Refine your problem statement to include a research question, expected data sources and structure, expected results and techniques.

Key Activities

  • Videos 16.1–16.6
  • Mini-Lesson 16.1
  • Required Knowledge Checks 16.1–16.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 16.1 and 16.2
  • Required Discussion 16.1
  • Required Capstone Assignment 16.1
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 16.1–16.6
Module 17: Practical Application 3

Learning Outcomes

  1. Apply various classification methods to a business problem.
  2. Compare the results of k-nearest neighbors, logistic regression, decision trees, and support vector machines.

Key Activities

  • Videos 17.1 and 17.2
  • Required Assignment 17.1
Module 18: Natural Language Processing (NLP)

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the similarities and differences between text and numerical data.
  2. Convert text data to numerical data using NLTK.
  3. Tokenize blocks of text.
  4. Decide what features to extract from a text for a particular classification purpose.
  5. Implement feature extraction using NLTK.
  6. Use Bag-of-Words and TF-IDF algorithms to convert text data to numerical representation.
  7. Classify text data using Bag-of-Words, TF-IDF, and logistic regression algorithms.
  8. Compare the results of classification on text data using several models.
  9. Apply the naïve Bayes classifier.

Key Activities

  • Videos 18.1–18.6
  • Mini-Lessons 18.1–18.7
  • Required Knowledge Checks 18.1–18.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 18.1–18.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 18.1–18.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 18.1
Module 19: Recommendation Systems

Learning Outcomes

  1. Compute missing ratings from a rating dataset.
  2. Evaluate the trade-off between the number of factors and model performance.
  3. Calculate users' predictions using linear regression.
  4. Utilize collaborative filtering to understand users' predictions.
  5. Implement the Simon Funk SVD gradient descent algorithm for collaborative filtering.
  6. Use the SURPRISE library to build and analyze recommender systems on real datasets.
  7. Articulate the significance of a hybrid recommendation system.
  8. Determine why a surprise recommendation may occur on a recommendation system.

Key Activities

  • Videos 19.1–19.9
  • Mini-Lessons 19.1–19.4
  • Required Knowledge Checks 19.1–19.6
  • Required Codio Assignments 19.1–19.3
  • Required Discussion 19.1
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 19.1–19.3
  • Self-Study Discussion 19.1
Module 20: Ensemble Techniques

Learning Outcomes

  1. Relate the concepts of bias and variance to real-world examples.
  2. Employ the concept of aggregating predictors for bagging in ensemble model.
  3. Build a metamodel for classification and regression problems.
  4. Evaluate the performance of various metamodels.
  5. Implement bootstrapping on a dataset.
  6. Implement bagging on a metamodel.
  7. Apply out-of-bag evaluation in scikit-learn.
  8. Articulate the key concepts and parameters of the Random Forest algorithm in scikit-learn.
  9. Design random forests for classification and regression problems.
  10. Implement the AdaBoost algorithm.
  11. Compare the AdaBoost algorithm with gradient boosted trees.
  12. Perform a deep analysis of your identified problem in order to develop an executive brief detailing your technical findings.

Key Activities

  • Videos 20.1–20.9
  • Mini-Lessons 20.1
  • Required Knowledge Checks 20.1–20.6
  • Required Try-It Activity 20.1
  • Required Codio Assignments 20.1–20.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 20.1–20.3
Module 21: Deep Neural Networks (Part 1)

Learning Outcomes

  1. Articulate the basics and evolution of neural networks.
  2. Compute the output of a neural network given parameters and data.
  3. Train a simple neural network.
  4. Apply the basics of Keras for developing machine learning models.
  5. Use Keras to create, compile, fit, and evaluate a model.
  6. Select the appropriate output layer and loss function for multiclass classification.
  7. Adjust hyperparameters and model architecture to maximize model generalizability.

Key Activities

  • Videos 21.1–21.9
  • Mini-Lessons 21.1 and 21.2
  • Required Knowledge Checks 21.1–21.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 21.1–21.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 21.1–21.6
Module 22: Deep Neural Networks (Part 2)

Learning Outcomes

  1. Articulate the basics of a CNN and its different layers.
  2. Process images in preparation for training a neural network.
  3. Train a neural network to recognize items and images.
  4. Use a pretrained network to enhance model performance.
  5. Interpret a neural network model.
  6. Compare an LSTM network to time series analysis.
  7. Train an LSTM network for time series analysis.
  8. Apply neural network techniques to a linear regression problem.
  9. Apply AI/ML techniques to a specific field you are interested in.

Key Activities

  • Videos 22.1–22.7
  • Mini-Lessons 22.1–22.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 22.1–22.3
  • Required Codio Assignments 22.1–22.5
  • Self-Study Discussion 22.1
  • Self-Study Try-It Activities 22.1–22.2
Module 23: Generative AI

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the limitations of generative techniques.
  2. Distinguish between the learning techniques of Gen AI.
  3. Configure a diffusion model to generate personalized AI images.
  4. Test different Gen AI models to compare similarities and differences.
  5. Generate a narrative using AI text generators in order to effectively evaluate data patterns.
  6. Calculate the similarity between sentences using transformers.
  7. Evaluate the effectiveness of Gen AI application examples.
  8. Identify current business applications of Gen AI technologies in finance, education, or healthcare.
  9. Generate a prompt for a Gen AI platform in order to analyze its effectiveness.

Key Activities

  • Videos 23.1–23.8
  • Mini-Lessons 23.1–23.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 23.1–23.2
  • Required Codio Assignment 23.1
  • Required Discussion 23.1-23.2
  • Required Assignment 23.1
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 23.1–23.2
  • Self-Study Discussions 23.1–23.2
Module 24: Capstone

Learning Outcomes

  1. Develop a nontechnical report for your comprehensive data solution that effectively addresses a real-world problem.

Key Activities

  • Video 24.1
  • Mini-Lesson 24.1
  • Required Capstone Project 24.1

  •  Part 2: Modules 7-12
  • Part 3: Modules 13-24

Foundations of Machine Learning and AI

Module 0: Program Orientation

Key Activities

  • Program Introduction
  • Learning Platform Overview
  • Introduce Yourself
  • Program Agreement
Module 1: Introduction to Machine Learning

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify examples of the mystery box metaphor within your industry or personal experience.
  2. Establish the correct ML notation and concepts.
  3. Determine measures of discrete vs. continuous probability functions.
  4. Distinguish between measures of central tendency.
  5. Search for two data sources online and examine their characteristics.
  6. Identify functions and codes related to DataFrames.
  7. Load data into a DataFrame using pandas.
  8. Analyze data using selection and statistical techniques.
  9. Analyze different data visualization techniques.
  10. Create histograms and data visualizations.

Key Activities

  • Videos 1.1–1.6
  • Mini-Lessons 1.1–1.5
  • Required Knowledge Checks 1.1–1.6
  • Required Discussions 1.1–1.3
  • Required Codio Activities 1.1–1.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activities 1.1 and 1.2
  • Self-Study Colab Activity 1.1
Module 2: Fundamentals of Statistics and Distribution Functions

Learning Outcomes

  1. Differentiate between normal and uniform distributions.
  2. Evaluate measures of uniform distribution using SciPy. 
  3. Create and interpret visual plots, including probability density functions, histograms, scatter plots, pair plots, and correlation matrices.
  4. Discuss applications of the central limit theorem.
  5. Compute the mean and variance of univariate Gaussian distributions.
  6. Apply the law of large numbers to a given population.
  7. Explain covariance and correlation in multivariate distributions.
  8. Plot multivariate datasets.
  9. Compute measures of central tendency for univariate and multivariate distributions using pandas.
  10. Interpret a sample covariance matrix using Python.
  11. Identify correlations from scatter plots and conditional probabilities.

Key Activities

  • Videos 2.1–2.6
  • Mini-Lessons 2.1–2.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 2.1–1.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 2.1–2.4
  • Self-Study Discussion 2.1
  • Self-Study Try-It Activities 2.1 and 2.2
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 2.1–2.4
Module 3: Introduction to Data Analysis

Learning Outcomes

  1. Discuss real-world contexts for the data science lifecycle.
  2. Demonstrate the uses of different pandas functions.
  3. Manipulate data given a dataset.
  4. Choose appropriate visualizing functions.
  5. Generate visualizations using pandas, seaborn, and Plotly.
  6. Customize plots using externally sourced documentation.
  7. Use pandas.groupby to manipulate data.
  8. Demonstrate sorting and aggregating operations using pandas.
  9. Perform computations between DataFrames using set index and reset index.
  10. Demonstrate different indexing and filtering techniques using pandas.

Key Activities

  • Videos 3.1–3.10
  • Mini-Lessons 3.1–3.2
  • Required Knowledge Checks 3.1–3.4
  • Required Discussion 3.1
  • Required Codio Assignments 3.1–3.4
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 3.1
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 3.1–3.3
Module 4: Fundamentals of Data Analysis

Learning Outcomes

  1. Demonstrate pandas.merge to join datasets.
  2. Use pandas.merge to join with multiple fields using multiple variables in pandas.
  3. Perform merge operations on datasets.
  4. Use different plotting techniques in Seaborn and Plotly with pandas DataFrame to visualize the data.
  5. Create a variety of plot types in pandas, Seaborn, and Plotly.
  6. Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of each plotting library.
  7. Perform string manipulation in pandas.
  8. Import and clean messy data from real-world datasets.

Key Activities

  • Videos 4.1–4.11
  • Mini-Lessons 4.1–4.4
  • Required Knowledge Checks 4.1–4.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 4.1–4.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 4.1-4.5
Module 5: Practical Application 1

Learning Outcomes

  1. Create a GitHub portfolio.
  2. Apply exploratory data analysis, plotting, statistical summarization, and data visualization skills and techniques to a machine learning problem.

Key Activities

  • Video 5.1
  • Required Assignment 5.1
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 5.1
  • Self-Study Discussion 5.1
Module 6: Data Clustering and Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

Learning Outcomes

  1. Apply SVD to a specific dataset.
  2. Analyze the results of PCA in a specific context.
  3. Interpret the singular value and the results of PCA.
  4. Apply the k-means algorithm in Python.
  5. Compare the two different ways of initializing centroids (k-means++ vs. random initialization).
  6. Compare results of multiple clustering techniques on a given dataset.
  7. Interpret the results of k-means and PCA given an initial dataset.
  8. Evaluate various clustering algorithms by examining the clustering shapes and their ability to detect outliers in a given dataset.
  9. Draft a problem statement.

Key Activities

  • Videos 6.1–6.8
  • Mini-Lessons 6.1–6.4
  • Required Knowledge Checks 6.1–6.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 6.1–6.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 6.1 and 6.2

Machine Learning and AI Techniques

Module 7: Linear and Multiple Regressions

Learning Outcomes

  1. Differentiate between a linear and nonlinear model.
  2. Fit a simple linear regression model using scikit-learn and Plotly.
  3. Compute loss in prediction in order to minimize it.
  4. Compute the squared error and absolute error.
  5. Apply the scipy.optimize function to minimize the loss function.
  6. Apply multiple techniques to minimize a loss function.
  7. Recognize the use of mean absolute error (MAE) and mean squared error (MSE).
  8. Predict outcomes using a multiple linear regression model.
  9. Recognize ordinal, nominal, and categorical data within a dataset.

Key Activities

  • Videos 7.1–7.12
  • Mini-Lessons 7.1–7.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 7.1–7.7
  • Required Codio Assignments 7.1–7.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 7.1–7.2
Module 8: Feature Engineering and Overfitting

Learning Outcomes

  1. Articulate model fitting for nonlinear features.
  2. Generate nonlinear features for use by a linear model.
  3. Describe the difference between inference and prediction.
  4. Use scikit-learn transformers for generating polynomial features and prediction.
  5. Demonstrate the uses of different pandas functions.
  6. Articulate the definitions and relationships yielded from overfitting.
  7. Analyze the relationship between generalization and overfitting.
  8. Evaluate the complexity of various pipeline models.
  9. Select the best model based on validation data.
  10. Use a validation set for model selection to avoid overfitting.
  11. Use a test set for final model evaluation.
  12. Create and evaluate a linear regression model with nonlinear features using scikit-learn.

Key Activities

  • Videos 8.1–8.10
  • Mini-Lessons 8.1–8.5
  • Required Knowledge Checks 8.1–8.7
  • Required Codio Assignments 8.1–8.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 8.1–8.4
Module 9: Model Selection and Regularization

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the effect of polynomial features on Multidimensional data.
  2. Utilize sequential feature selection to explore model complexity.
  3. Apply regularization to control model complexity.
  4. Use regularization parameter "alpha" in ridge regression.
  5. Employ StandardScalar in ridge regularization.
  6. Scale data using standardization to avoid over-penalizing features in a regularized model.
  7. Apply GridSearchCV to select the optimal value for alpha.
  8. Select features using Lasso regression.
  9. Evaluate the differences between leave-one-out cross-validation, K-fold cross-validation, and holdout cross-validation.

Key Activities

  • Videos 9.1–9.11
  • Required Knowledge Checks 9.1–9.8
  • Required Codio Assignments 9.1–9.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 9.1–9.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 9.1
  • Self-Study Discussion 9.1
Module 10: Time Series Analysis and Forecasting

Learning Outcomes

  1. Describe the forecasting problem.
  2. Use modeling in time series forecasting with the effect of autocorrelations.
  3. Compute the sample autocorrelation and partial autocorrelation functions for a time series.
  4. Construct a model using classical time series decomposition.
  5. Differentiate between key characteristics of the autoregressive model and moving average model.
  6. Use the ACF and PACF to select the orders of an ARMA model.
  7. Interpret a forecast and its uncertainty.
  8. Determine the invertibility and stationarity of ARMA model and use ACF and PACF to select the order of ARMA model.

Key Activities

  • Videos 10.1–10.13
  • Mini-Lessons 10.1 and 10.2
  • Required Knowledge Checks 10.1–10.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 10.1–10.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 10.1–10.3
Module 11: Practical Application 2

Learning Outcomes

  1. Apply the CRISP-DM framework to a business problem.

Key Activities

  • Videos 11.1 and 11.2
  • Required Assignment 11.1
Module 12: Classification and k-Nearest Neighbors

Learning Outcomes

  1. Explain the concept of classification with an email spam detection example.
  2. Train a nearest neighbor classifier using cross-validation.
  3. Use k to minimize misclassification error.
  4. Use cross-validation to pick hyperparameters that optimize the metric of your choosing.
  5. Describe the effect on threshold and choice of k using the predict_proba function in scikit-learn.
  6. Create a visualization of KNN decision boundaries as a function of k and threshold.
  7. Assess the trade-offs between classifier metrics.
  8. Compute the real value output by using a regression function with KNN.
  9. Compare the accuracy and interpretability of a properly trained linear regression and a KNN regression model.

Key Activities

  • Videos 12.1–12.10
  • Mini-Lessons 12.1–12.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 12.1–12.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 12.1–12.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 12.1–12.3

Advanced Topics and Capstone

Module 13: Logistic Regression

Learning Outcomes

  1. Analyze the characteristics and advantages of logistic regression.
  2. Use the scikit-learn framework to solve a basic logistic regression problem.
  3. Utilize logistic regression for business decision-making.
  4. Practice illustrating logistic regression as an optimization problem to determine the coefficients to minimize cross-entropy.
  5. Implement strategies to visualize decision boundaries for two variables.
  6. Evaluate the cross-entropy for a range of parameters.
  7. Apply logistic regression to generate multiclass outputs.
  8. Use L1 regularization to select features.
  9. Assess multiple models using performance metrics.

Key Activities

  • Videos 13.1–13.7
  • Mini-Lesson 13.1
  • Required Knowledge Checks 13.1–13.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 13.1–13.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 13.1–13.4

  1. Identify the correct statements regarding decision trees and their outputs.
  2. Build a decision tree manually.

  5. Visualize a decision tree.
  6. Evaluate decision tree splits.
  7. Evaluate overfitting of decision trees.
  8. Measure the impurity of a decision tree using entropy.
  9. Compare the performance of different grid search algorithms.
  10. Implement the decision tree algorithm.

Module 23: Generative AI

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the limitations of generative techniques.
  2. Distinguish between the learning techniques of Gen AI.
  3. Configure a diffusion model to generate personalized AI images.
  4. Test different Gen AI models to compare similarities and differences.
  5. Generate a narrative using AI text generators in order to effectively evaluate data patterns.
  6. Calculate the similarity between sentences using transformers.
  7. Evaluate the effectiveness of Gen AI application examples.
  8. Identify current business applications of Gen AI technologies in finance, education, or healthcare.
  9. Generate a prompt for a Gen AI platform in order to analyze its effectiveness.

Key Activities

  • Videos 23.1–23.8
  • Mini-Lessons 23.1–23.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 23.1–23.2
  • Required Codio Assignment 23.1
  • Required Discussion 23.1-23.2
  • Required Assignment 23.1
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 23.1–23.2
  • Self-Study Discussions 23.1–23.2

Learning Outcomes

  1. Develop a nontechnical report for your comprehensive data solution that effectively addresses a real-world problem.

Key Activities

  • Video 24.1
  • Mini-Lesson 24.1
  • Required Capstone Project 24.1

Foundations of Machine Learning and AI

Module 0: Program Orientation

Key Activities

  • Program Introduction
  • Learning Platform Overview
  • Introduce Yourself
  • Program Agreement
Module 1: Introduction to Machine Learning

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify examples of the mystery box metaphor within your industry or personal experience.
  2. Establish the correct ML notation and concepts.
  3. Determine measures of discrete vs. continuous probability functions.
  4. Distinguish between measures of central tendency.
  5. Search for two data sources online and examine their characteristics.
  6. Identify functions and codes related to DataFrames.
  7. Load data into a DataFrame using pandas.
  8. Analyze data using selection and statistical techniques.
  9. Analyze different data visualization techniques.
  10. Create histograms and data visualizations.

Key Activities

  • Videos 1.1–1.6
  • Mini-Lessons 1.1–1.5
  • Required Knowledge Checks 1.1–1.6
  • Required Discussions 1.1–1.3
  • Required Codio Activities 1.1–1.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activities 1.1 and 1.2
  • Self-Study Colab Activity 1.1
Module 2: Fundamentals of Statistics and Distribution Functions

Learning Outcomes

  1. Differentiate between normal and uniform distributions.
  2. Evaluate measures of uniform distribution using SciPy. 
  3. Create and interpret visual plots, including probability density functions, histograms, scatter plots, pair plots, and correlation matrices.
  4. Discuss applications of the central limit theorem.
  5. Compute the mean and variance of univariate Gaussian distributions.
  6. Apply the law of large numbers to a given population.
  7. Explain covariance and correlation in multivariate distributions.
  8. Plot multivariate datasets.
  9. Compute measures of central tendency for univariate and multivariate distributions using pandas.
  10. Interpret a sample covariance matrix using Python.
  11. Identify correlations from scatter plots and conditional probabilities.

Key Activities

  • Videos 2.1–2.6
  • Mini-Lessons 2.1–2.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 2.1–1.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 2.1–2.4
  • Self-Study Discussion 2.1
  • Self-Study Try-It Activities 2.1 and 2.2
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 2.1–2.4
Module 3: Introduction to Data Analysis

Learning Outcomes

  1. Discuss real-world contexts for the data science lifecycle.
  2. Demonstrate the uses of different pandas functions.
  3. Manipulate data given a dataset.
  4. Choose appropriate visualizing functions.
  5. Generate visualizations using pandas, seaborn, and Plotly.
  6. Customize plots using externally sourced documentation.
  7. Use pandas.groupby to manipulate data.
  8. Demonstrate sorting and aggregating operations using pandas.
  9. Perform computations between DataFrames using set index and reset index.
  10. Demonstrate different indexing and filtering techniques using pandas.

Key Activities

  • Videos 3.1–3.10
  • Mini-Lessons 3.1–3.2
  • Required Knowledge Checks 3.1–3.4
  • Required Discussion 3.1
  • Required Codio Assignments 3.1–3.4
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 3.1
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 3.1–3.3
Module 4: Fundamentals of Data Analysis

Learning Outcomes

  1. Demonstrate pandas.merge to join datasets.
  2. Use pandas.merge to join with multiple fields using multiple variables in pandas.
  3. Perform merge operations on datasets.
  4. Use different plotting techniques in Seaborn and Plotly with pandas DataFrame to visualize the data.
  5. Create a variety of plot types in pandas, Seaborn, and Plotly.
  6. Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of each plotting library.
  7. Perform string manipulation in pandas.
  8. Import and clean messy data from real-world datasets.

Key Activities

  • Videos 4.1–4.11
  • Mini-Lessons 4.1–4.4
  • Required Knowledge Checks 4.1–4.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 4.1–4.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 4.1-4.5

Learning Outcomes

  1. Create a GitHub portfolio.
  2. Apply exploratory data analysis, plotting, statistical summarization, and data visualization skills and techniques to a machine learning problem.

Module 6: Data Clustering and Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

Learning Outcomes

  1. Apply SVD to a specific dataset.
  2. Analyze the results of PCA in a specific context.
  3. Interpret the singular value and the results of PCA.
  4. Apply the k-means algorithm in Python.
  5. Compare the two different ways of initializing centroids (k-means++ vs. random initialization).
  6. Compare results of multiple clustering techniques on a given dataset.
  7. Interpret the results of k-means and PCA given an initial dataset.
  8. Evaluate various clustering algorithms by examining the clustering shapes and their ability to detect outliers in a given dataset.
  9. Draft a problem statement.

Key Activities

  • Videos 6.1–6.8
  • Mini-Lessons 6.1–6.4
  • Required Knowledge Checks 6.1–6.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 6.1–6.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 6.1 and 6.2

Machine Learning and AI Techniques

Module 7: Linear and Multiple Regressions

Learning Outcomes

  1. Differentiate between a linear and nonlinear model.
  2. Fit a simple linear regression model using scikit-learn and Plotly.
  3. Compute loss in prediction in order to minimize it.
  4. Compute the squared error and absolute error.
  5. Apply the scipy.optimize function to minimize the loss function.
  6. Apply multiple techniques to minimize a loss function.
  7. Recognize the use of mean absolute error (MAE) and mean squared error (MSE).
  8. Predict outcomes using a multiple linear regression model.
  9. Recognize ordinal, nominal, and categorical data within a dataset.

Key Activities

  • Videos 7.1–7.12
  • Mini-Lessons 7.1–7.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 7.1–7.7
  • Required Codio Assignments 7.1–7.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 7.1–7.2
Module 8: Feature Engineering and Overfitting

Learning Outcomes

  1. Articulate model fitting for nonlinear features.
  2. Generate nonlinear features for use by a linear model.
  3. Describe the difference between inference and prediction.
  4. Use scikit-learn transformers for generating polynomial features and prediction.
  5. Demonstrate the uses of different pandas functions.
  6. Articulate the definitions and relationships yielded from overfitting.
  7. Analyze the relationship between generalization and overfitting.
  8. Evaluate the complexity of various pipeline models.
  9. Select the best model based on validation data.
  10. Use a validation set for model selection to avoid overfitting.
  11. Use a test set for final model evaluation.
  12. Create and evaluate a linear regression model with nonlinear features using scikit-learn.

Key Activities

  • Videos 8.1–8.10
  • Mini-Lessons 8.1–8.5
  • Required Knowledge Checks 8.1–8.7
  • Required Codio Assignments 8.1–8.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 8.1–8.4
Module 9: Model Selection and Regularization

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the effect of polynomial features on Multidimensional data.
  2. Utilize sequential feature selection to explore model complexity.
  3. Apply regularization to control model complexity.
  4. Use regularization parameter "alpha" in ridge regression.
  5. Employ StandardScalar in ridge regularization.
  6. Scale data using standardization to avoid over-penalizing features in a regularized model.
  7. Apply GridSearchCV to select the optimal value for alpha.
  8. Select features using Lasso regression.
  9. Evaluate the differences between leave-one-out cross-validation, K-fold cross-validation, and holdout cross-validation.

Key Activities

  • Videos 9.1–9.11
  • Required Knowledge Checks 9.1–9.8
  • Required Codio Assignments 9.1–9.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 9.1–9.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 9.1
  • Self-Study Discussion 9.1
Module 10: Time Series Analysis and Forecasting

Learning Outcomes

  1. Describe the forecasting problem.
  2. Use modeling in time series forecasting with the effect of autocorrelations.
  3. Compute the sample autocorrelation and partial autocorrelation functions for a time series.
  4. Construct a model using classical time series decomposition.
  5. Differentiate between key characteristics of the autoregressive model and moving average model.
  6. Use the ACF and PACF to select the orders of an ARMA model.
  7. Interpret a forecast and its uncertainty.
  8. Determine the invertibility and stationarity of ARMA model and use ACF and PACF to select the order of ARMA model.

Key Activities

  • Videos 10.1–10.13
  • Mini-Lessons 10.1 and 10.2
  • Required Knowledge Checks 10.1–10.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 10.1–10.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 10.1–10.3
Module 11: Practical Application 2

Learning Outcomes

  1. Apply the CRISP-DM framework to a business problem.

Key Activities

  • Videos 11.1 and 11.2
  • Required Assignment 11.1
Module 12: Classification and k-Nearest Neighbors

Learning Outcomes

  1. Explain the concept of classification with an email spam detection example.
  2. Train a nearest neighbor classifier using cross-validation.
  3. Use k to minimize misclassification error.
  4. Use cross-validation to pick hyperparameters that optimize the metric of your choosing.
  5. Describe the effect on threshold and choice of k using the predict_proba function in scikit-learn.
  6. Create a visualization of KNN decision boundaries as a function of k and threshold.
  7. Assess the trade-offs between classifier metrics.
  8. Compute the real value output by using a regression function with KNN.
  9. Compare the accuracy and interpretability of a properly trained linear regression and a KNN regression model.

Key Activities

  • Videos 12.1–12.10
  • Mini-Lessons 12.1–12.3
  • Required Knowledge Checks 12.1–12.5
  • Required Codio Assignments 12.1–12.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 12.1–12.3

Advanced Topics and Capstone

Module 13: Logistic Regression

Learning Outcomes

  1. Analyze the characteristics and advantages of logistic regression.
  2. Use the scikit-learn framework to solve a basic logistic regression problem.
  3. Utilize logistic regression for business decision-making.
  4. Practice illustrating logistic regression as an optimization problem to determine the coefficients to minimize cross-entropy.
  5. Implement strategies to visualize decision boundaries for two variables.
  6. Evaluate the cross-entropy for a range of parameters.
  7. Apply logistic regression to generate multiclass outputs.
  8. Use L1 regularization to select features.
  9. Assess multiple models using performance metrics.

Key Activities

  • Videos 13.1–13.7
  • Mini-Lesson 13.1
  • Required Knowledge Checks 13.1–13.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 13.1–13.3
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 13.1–13.4
Module 14: Decision Trees

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify the correct statements regarding decision trees and their outputs.
  2. Build a decision tree manually.
  3. Articulate the correct inputs for building decision trees using scikit-learn and visualizing them using Graphiz.
  4. Train a decision tree model with desired hyperparameters using scikit-learn.
  5. Visualize a decision tree.
  6. Evaluate decision tree splits.
  7. Evaluate overfitting of decision trees.
  8. Measure the impurity of a decision tree using entropy.
  9. Compare the performance of different grid search algorithms.
  10. Implement the decision tree algorithm.

Key Activities

  • Videos 14.1–14.11
  • Mini-Lessons 14.1–14.5
  • Required Knowledge Checks 14.1–14.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 14.1–14.3
  • Required Discussion 14.1
  • Required Try-It Activity 14.2
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 14.1–14.3
  • Self-Study Try-It Activity 14.1
Module 15: Gradient Descent and Optimization

Learning Outcomes

  1. Compute the approximate value of a function using its derivative.
  2. Identify the basics of gradient descent and the impact of learning rate on convergence.
  3. Compute x and/or y for each iteration of gradient descent.
  4. Optimize a single-parameter linear regression model from scratch.
  5. Recognize convex one-dimensional and two-dimensional functions.
  6. Compute the gradient of a two-dimensional function.
  7. Measure the impurity of a decision tree using entropy.
  8. Use gradient descent to optimize a nonlinear two-dimensional regression model.
  9. Use stochastic gradient descent to optimize a nonlinear two-dimensional regression model.
  10. Compare the convergence behavior of gradient descent with stochastic gradient descent.
  11. Articulate the impact of stochastic gradient on bias and variance.

Key Activities

  • Videos 15.1–15.15
  • Required Knowledge Checks 15.1–15.6
  • Required Codio Assignments 15.1–15.4
  • Self-Study Colab Activities 15.1–15.4
Module 16: Classifying Nonlinear Features

Learning Outcomes

  1. Identify nonlinear features in a dataset.
  2. Compare classification models to assess boundary definitions.
  3. Apply kernels to logistic regression models to automatically build nonlinear boundaries.
  4. Compare large- and small-margin classifiers.
  5. Calculate the maximum margin given a dataset.
  6. Create maximum margin classifier visualizations in scikit-learn.
  7. Articulate the working of the kernel functions in SVM using scikit-learn.
  8. Tune kernel and regularization parameters given a dataset.
  9. Discuss the results and trade-offs of various techniques.
  10. Refine your problem statement to include a research question, expected data sources and structure, expected results and techniques.

Key Activities

  • Videos 16.1–16.6
  • Mini-Lesson 16.1
  • Required Knowledge Checks 16.1–16.4
  • Required Codio Assignments 16.1 and 16.2

  • Self-Study Colab Activities 16.1–16.6

Learning Outcomes

  1. Apply various classification methods to a business problem.
  2. Compare the results of k-nearest neighbors, logistic regression, decision trees, and support vector machines.
